Pros:
I decided to wait almost a year after leaving the company before posting a review.  The primary reason being is that when you decide to leave an organization it is usually because there is something there that isn't aligning with you or what you want anymore however, the grass is not always greener someplace else.  This has been my experience.  In fact, the appreciation I have for the company has grown so much in my time away that I would really like to return.

The company truly believes on promoting within and as an employee you are encouraged to grow your career within the organization and learn new skills by taking different positions.  Benefits are excellent.  Cisco is the industry leader for networking and now cloud.  It is sometimes easy to forget that on the daily grind but you are working for the company that everyone looks to for network and infrastructure standards.  Culture within the business units managing product lines give you a lot of freedom to be innovative and creative in your approach to your role.  In most cases you are given a fair amount of autonomy and control over how you do your job provided that it aligns with the strategic objectives.  Benefits, 401k match, RSUs and ESPP are amazing.  And while the salaries aren't the top of the industry, they are above market and pretty competitive.
Cons:
Cisco can be a machine.  There isn't an overt demand for all of your time (even the time outside of work) but more of a subtle, slight encouragement to always be on.  If you are not careful, you will live, sleep and eat Cisco 24x7.  Don't get me wrong, this is 100% a choice and if you are aware of this subtlety in the culture it is very easy to set appropriate boundaries that will be respected by the company and leadership team.

If you don't like where you are in Cisco or what you are working on, give it 6 months because you will be reorg'd.  While it is sometimes necessary to realign the company to meet competitive threats or market demands, reorganizing the company once a year is excessive and tends to create a distrusting environment for the rank and file which makes being a leader in the organize challenging.  There is a loss of momentum and motivation that occurs a few months before and a few months after reorgs so this leaves the company being effective at delivery and execution only about 70% of the time.

While Cisco attracts some bright, motivated people the truth of the matter is you are either cut out for the company and its culture or you're not.  If you aren't it will be painfully obvious to you and those around you.  Sadly as a leader it is hard to cut dead weight from the team and the only really accepted way is via layoffs, which is why the company reorgs once a year despite the company line about the reorgs.

Pros: Overall, Cisco is a good place to work. As a senior systems engineer, I had the opportunity to collaborate with many thoughtful, capable, and genuine people across teams—from engineering and test to compliance, product management, executives, manufacturing, and TAC. The company encourages technical excellence, and there are pockets of genuinely supportive leadership. That said, the experience can vary dramatically depending on your org and manager, and some managers operate with impunity despite repeated and serious concerns.
Cons:
If you end up with a manager who manipulates systems and relationships—undermining direct reports, peers, and even superiors to secure promotion or survival—the only real option is to leave. Don’t expect HR, ER, or internal processes to intervene meaningfully, even when misconduct is extensively documented and corroborated by multiple witnesses. This toxic behavior often goes unpunished and actively rewarded—with visibility, advancement, incentives, and plenty of opportunities to retaliate against those who speak up.

Cisco has trimmed HR/ER and internal enforcement functions so much that the cultural messaging from the Cisco People Office feels performative and aspirational rather than reflective of ground-level realities.

Pros:
Grow and learn with some genuinely smart and capable folks
Prestige of working for the market leader
Stays innovative through some great external acquisitions
Good internal tools and work resources
Overall a supportive company culture
Cons:
The 'old guard' of Cisco can be quite bureaucratic and political. You will discover that more innovative/more approachable/results driven leadership comes in from external acquisitions rather than long time senior employees.

After a certain point, growth heavily hinges on somebody senior 'sponsoring' you. Ergo, high performance on its own will not open doors at the upper middle to senior manager level.

It's a big company (~80K employees). Things can get lost.

Pros: Cisco offers a truly flexible hybrid work environment, which makes it easier to maintain a healthy work-life balance. The team I work with is incredibly supportive, collaborative, and open to new ideas. The culture promotes learning, growth, and inclusion. Leadership is approachable and transparent. Overall, it's a positive and empowering place to work.
Cons: None so far – I've had a great experience.

Pros: As a Programme Manager at Cisco, my role involved school visits and leading the LittleBigAwards campaign.
Cons: I made the difficult decision to leave Cisco because I wanted to work in an environment where accessibility, inclusion, and opportunities for growth were prioritised. While I appreciated many aspects of the company, the lack of true disability inclusion and the ongoing uncertainty from constant reorganisations pushed me to seek a more supportive and empowering workplace.

Pros: Chill work life balance and long paternity leave if you need it.
Cons:
I felt it was a cost cutting place. 
Did not even have company sponsored team dinners and no one knows which direction to work on. Sort of like a ruder less ship.
It did not feel like a top IT place. It had a lot of very average people most of whom had only masters from only a few select colleges i.e. the ones that the seniors belonged to. Low level of tech expertise is needed and most higher level people didn't understand much advanced ML stuff. Much higher importance was given to visibility than actual innovation and being managers pet will take you a long way.

CISCO India is the best place to be.  people managers are desginated as  engineering managers , but when it comes  to technical cappabilties are pathetic. You just need one skill - micro management. Cons:
Beyond 10 years of experience. you will murder your techical carrier growth . There is now cutting edge technical work moving to india.  CISCO India Less 0.5% have any meaning ful growth.  These are the chosen onces by VP/ Director , who are given RSUs more oftern. RSUs distribution is always done in close doors and its opaque. you will not even know if a quarter has budget for that . Very few coming from external hired make a mark.

Worst thing is you will end up reporting to your buddy / colleague - or may be junior who chose to be people manager , than being in technical ( not even having management degrees) . No matter , the person could be technical background,  be even 50% of your capapbilities. But he is well oiled in the system .

Salaries for pure technical individual contributors can be compared by service companies once you complete 5 years of normalization.

Pros: None. Hope it could be better.
Cons:
The decision-making style within this historic IT company often reminds me of the unpredictability seen in broad policy shifts like the Trump-era tariffs — top-down directives issued without adequate consideration for on-the-ground realities. In some cases, organizational restructures have been implemented without fully understanding product segmentation, technical distinctions, or how various solutions align with customer needs. This has led to inefficiencies and friction among teams.

There’s also a noticeable tendency toward rigid, hierarchical leadership — occasionally influenced by a militaristic mindset — which can stifle open communication and discourage constructive feedback. When leadership becomes overly dominant or insulated, particularly at the regional level, it hampers effective decision-making and fosters an unhealthy work environment.

Moreover, the company’s global alignment remains inconsistent. Reporting lines still vary by country, and unequal treatment of product-side teams by account-side stakeholders reflects broader issues in organizational equity. These structural imbalances need to be addressed to create a truly collaborative and fair working culture.

Pros:
I honestly can't speak highly enough about my experience at Cisco. From day one, it's been clear that this is a company that genuinely prioritizes its employees.

The Work-Life Balance (WLB) is truly outstanding – it's not just a buzzword here, it's deeply ingrained in the culture. Leadership actively encourages you to disconnect, take time off, and manage your schedule flexibly. Whether it's managing family commitments, personal appointments, or just needing time to recharge, Cisco provides the flexibility and support to ensure work seamlessly integrates into your life, rather than dominating it. Burnout is not a factor here; instead, there's a strong emphasis on sustainable productivity and employee well-being.

Compensation and Benefits are also exceptionally good. The pay is highly competitive, reflecting the value employees bring. Beyond a great base salary, the comprehensive benefits package (health, 401k match, generous PTO, and potential for bonuses/RSUs) is fantastic. I feel truly valued and fairly compensated for my contributions.

Beyond these two major points, the culture is incredibly collaborative and supportive. You're surrounded by brilliant, kind, and approachable colleagues. There are ample opportunities for learning and growth, whether through internal programs, mentorship, or working on cutting-edge projects. Cisco's commitment to innovation and social impact (diversity, sustainability) also makes it a truly rewarding place to work. It's a company where you can feel proud of what you're contributing to."
Cons: Honestly, it's genuinely challenging to pinpoint any significant 'cons' that detract from the overwhelmingly positive experience at Cisco. My experience here has consistently exceeded expectations. If I had to stretch to identify a 'con,' perhaps the sheer size of the organization means navigating certain internal processes can sometimes take a moment, but teams are always helpful and resources are abundant. This is a truly minor point within a sea of positives.

Pros:
Prestigious Global Brand: Working at Cisco offers strong name recognition and credibility on your resume.
Smart, Collaborative Teams: Surrounded by talented professionals who are often willing to share knowledge and support cross-functional collaboration.
Flexible Work Environment: Hybrid/remote work culture with a focus on results over face time, depending on the team.
Great Benefits: Comprehensive healthcare, generous PTO, 401(k) match, employee stock purchase plan, and wellness programs.
Diversity & Inclusion Efforts: Cisco invests in employee resource groups and DEI initiatives, making it a welcoming environment for many.
Opportunities for Internal Mobility: Easier to explore lateral moves across functions and teams if you network internally.
Access to Tools & Resources: Top-tier platforms and internal tools to help with data, automation, and process improvement.
Cons:
Frequent Restructuring: Ongoing reorgs can create uncertainty, limit long-term planning, and cause disruption in team dynamics.
Limited Promotion Path in Operations: Roles in Partner/Channel Operations may not have as clear or fast a path to leadership as Sales or Engineering.
Bureaucracy & Siloed Teams: Large company dynamics can slow down decision-making and cross-functional execution.
Inconsistent Leadership Styles: Experience can vary widely depending on your direct manager and org alignment.
Visibility Can Be a Challenge: Ops roles supporting Sales may be under-recognized despite their strategic impact.
Pressure During QBRs/FY Planning: especially during sales cycles and end-of-quarter crunches.

Pros:
A relaxed work environment and a pleasant atmosphere.
Good work-life balance.
Competitive salary and numerous benefits (lots of vacation days, quarterly team-building budget, ESPP).
You will be using Java, Python, C/C++, Git, Maven, Jenkins, Linux, Jetbrains IDEs, Github Copilot and MacBooks.
You will get a free subscription to Udemy, Coursera, LinkedIn Learn and more.
Cons:
Most people are average and not ambitious.
An old, large, and cumbersome product (ISE).
Lots of spaghetti code.
Very little development. Most of the work involves maintaining tests and fixing bugs (the product is poorly written).
No one knows the system well enough in depth, and when changes are made to one flow, it's not always possible to predict how other flows will be affected.
The managers are focused on trivial matters rather than the main issues. For example, they concentrate on test code coverage instead of its quality. As a result, many tests cover the code without actually checking anything.
Old architecture. No micro-services and no cloud.

Cisco could do a better job making information about employee development programs known as they have various programs, but sometimes you just find out randomly through word of mouth. Even if someone needs to be nominated for a program, the employees should know they exist.

Cons: It’s a big company, so sometimes things move slower, but overall, it was a great first step in my career.

Pros: Good pay and benefits. Lots of smart, hard working, driven co-workers. Challenging projects to work on. 80 hours of time to give per year (volunteer time), unlimited PTO, 6 days for me annually, birthday off, 10+ holidays per year in United States.
Cons: Lay-offs continue to impact morale, and most teams are short-staffed and working long hours. The executive level politics are skilling the company. Lots of exec level turn-over . There is a clear feeling that the execs SAY they care about employees, but their actions speak more loudly that they do NOT care. The work-life balance is suffering for many.

Pros:
- Cisco’s brand name boosts your resume.
- Exposure to a wide range of IT and cybersecurity products. Free certifications & courses that are recognised worldwide.
- You’ll learn a lot—mostly because you’re forced to wear multiple hats.
- Lots of GREAT colleagues who try to support each other under pressure. They're some of the nicest workmates you'll ever end up working with.
Cons:
- After the mass layoff, workloads doubled, but salaries stayed the same. Management’s answer: "budget constraints." Nothing changes - well, not in your favour anyways. But policy and workload changes? A lot.
- You're expected to do more than what you were officially hired for - lead generation, qualification, technical guidance, account creation, and pseudo-account management—but you're still treated and paid like a basic lead qualifier. Commissions are even capped. Imagine closing a deal more than 600k in a single week, but your commission didn't even reflect 1% of that achievement. Instead, rewards are given in the form of cash vouchers or gift cards.
- That being said; no career growth & no clear progression from management. Lots of GREAT people have left just because you're so busy focusing on the wrong things. You're punishing TOP achievers just because they don't follow your note-keeping style?? ridiculous.
- Recognition is scarce. You keep the engine running, but it feels like you’re invisible unless something goes wrong. Each quarterly meeting is spent on celebrating wins that didn't even reflect back to the team members' contribution.
- "Work-life balance" is for other teams & upper management. For the rest of us, it's 5 days in the office & you can only make calls at your own desk, not in any of the designated quiet room. Reason being: they want to SEE & HEAR you make the calls. As if we don't use recording tools. Micromanagement at its peak.
- Leadership is disconnected from day-to-day struggles. Feedback feels like it goes into a black hole. Pointless. Weekly check ins? Useless.

Pros: Best For Work Life Balance
Cons: Frequent Layoff Unstability, old technologies

Pros:
Amazing Cisco culture and growth opportunities, best globally. 
Super learning opportunities and great technologies
Cons:
CCBU is generally a great place to work, but unfortunately, a few handful unfit so called managers have severely impacted the environment. In some teams, the toxicity is particularly rampant, and it goes unchecked because two individuals are enabling unethical behavior , and its unchecked totally, as developers fear their job , as they will threathen them with dire consequences.

Person KK, who is abusive and egotistical, constantly demands respect, claiming to be the key to the team’s success while threatening others with consequences, if he is not respected. Person NS, a close friend of K's wife, that everyone must support him, and blindly will follow him, technically NS himself will not know anything.

In this dysfunctional environment, any task that doesn't get done is automatically attributed by a threat to talk to KK. The team works tirelessly, yet NS takes all the credit, while KK rewards him for it and never the team. If you don’t meet expectations, NS will relentlessly contact you—calling, texting, and reach out non stop on whats-app and even reaching out to your family, all while disregarding any personal boundaries. 

N's only role seems to be demanding ETAs with no planning or structure, undermining Cisco’s otherwise amazing culture.

This stressful environemnt persists only because both K and N protect each other’s interests. I was ill and I could not even get up, my father was contacted on phone as to where is your son and while I was sick with a high fever. The mental stress I endured is ongoing as only one person listens who is in USA, and he is unaware of these folks. As a developer I am not able to work on new technologies and upcomign features and techstack.
Thats how talent dies.
My peers in Vendor company were tortured mentally even in pregnancy.

Cisco is a wonderful company, but this one team under Kk and N’s so called titled leadership is a glaring exception.

Job Title: Leaders in finance and technology (lift), financial analyst
Pros: I completed Cisco's LIFT Program and was initially excited by its strong reputation in the Cisco community. The program was once an esteemed and highly respected path for early-career development, but unfortunately, things have gone downhill under the current management.
Cons:
Leadership has been particularly problematic. He is difficult to work with, and I personally observed a sexist bias within the program. It was clear that male participants were promoted more frequently than women, which was a shared concern among my graduating class.

The program consists of four rotations and four LIFT academies. While these academies are meant to support development, in practice, they lack fairness. Assessments are inconsistent, and favoritism is common. Performance doesn’t always seem to matter. For instance, the “top performer” in my group was actually absent on vacation for a large part of the timeline, and despite multiple complaints about their performance, program management ignored these concerns and selected that person as the only one from our group to receive LIFT honors.

The current class is regarded as having a poor attitude, often logging in after 11 a.m. and frequently complaining. 

Overall, if you're one of Tim’s favorites, you may have a smoother path, but if not, expect to face politics rather than professional growth. The LIFT Program needs strong, unbiased leadership to restore its reputation and value.

Pros:
+ pleasant atmosphere at work. Most people are not just bots hanging around 
+ helpful colleagues
+ lots of respect and trust from the middle management. There is no problem with getting a sick leave at all (big +)
+ salary (around 110% of the average)
+ occasional trips to the office (once every 5-6 months) fully paid by the company
Cons:
+ Individual performance (your customers' satisfaction and review etc.) is overshadowed by your reputation. It takes one person's negative opinion about you to lose a big portion of a pay rise. In other words, you need to behave like the company wants you to behave. This is why criticism is not welcomed in practice.
+ little to no opportunities in some departments and locations, Poland especially
+ a lot of bureocracy
+ work flexibility (schedule/calendar) is getting lower with each year. I.e. In theory you can move lunch slots to other hour, but in reality the system does not allow for that as there is not enough staff at almost every hour of the day.

Pros: Cisco has many tools and very smart people working for the company. I have been here almost 10 years and it was the company I planned to retire with, but with all the recent change people are silently quitting. There is still alot of good going on but it gets harder to see it when there is so much negative impact and people are so unhappy.
Cons: The company has changed the compensation model so many times over the last few years I can't even count - There is no budget to travel. I run a sales team that supports America and literally am given 1,500/ quarter for each seller to support their customers in person. This is a joke and it has been going on for 4 quarters. Also the compensation model for all sellers is terrible. Cisco pays a decelerated amount until sellers hit 50% of their number then from 50-75% a slight accelerated number to make up for the decelerator - then paid out at 100% once seller hits 75%. This is terrible especially for GES and public sector sellers who many times pull in 30-50% of their revenue in Q4. Not to mention we have lay off's constantly and 0 stability at the SLT level . I don't even recognize this company .

Pros:
Excellent environment for professional growth and skill development, especially in customer support roles.
High focus on customer satisfaction, with tools and processes that help achieve exceptional results.
Opportunity to work with a diverse, global team, benefiting from cross-cultural collaboration.
Flexibility in work schedules, with support for remote work and accommodating different time zones.
Strong emphasis on employee development, from onboarding to cultural interviews for team alignment.
Company invests in resources that empower employees to succeed, fostering a culture of support and innovation.
Cons:
Recent layoffs and department closures, which were a result of company strategies rather than employee performance, have impacted job security and overall morale.
Limited clarity on the long-term strategy of some departments, especially in technical consulting and customer support roles.
Some departments may experience understaffing issues, particularly in critical weekend shifts, leading to increased pressure on the existing team.

Pros:
Good work-life balance.
Flexible working arrangements.
Average benefits.
Cons:
Cisco has become an extremely unstable company. Every year I worked there, there were layoffs, and now layoffs have become a regular occurrence. In my last year alone, there were three rounds of layoffs, which clearly indicates that management lacks direction. Instead of implementing a strong long-term strategy, leadership continuously resorts to downsizing, showing a complete lack of vision for the company's future.

Additionally, many management and director-level roles are assigned to individuals with little to no relevant experience. This leads to poor decision-making and a lack of leadership. Collaboration between teams is nearly nonexistent, with constant conflicts between the so-called global teams and regional teams. The work environment is toxic, and promotions are not based on hard work or expertise but rather on internal connections and favoritism.

Salaries are below industry average, and salary increases are rare. If you're expecting regular raises, good luck—because they barely happen. Any employee benefits or initiatives seem to be purely for show rather than genuine care for employees. One glaring example was when the company was publicly celebrating being voted a "Best Place to Work" in the morning, only to start laying off employees that same afternoon. This was handled in an unprofessional and insensitive manner, proving that most of Cisco's employee initiatives are just for appearances.

Internal structures and processes are outdated and dysfunctional, yet no one takes meaningful action to fix them. Instead of addressing inefficiencies, the company always chooses the easy way out—layoffs. They don't even attempt to reallocate employees to other internal positions when teams are restructured. Instead, they lay off existing employees and hire new ones for similar roles.

If you don’t mind constant instability, poor leadership, and a company that prioritizes image over employee well-being, then Cisco might be the place for you. But if you’re looking for long-term stability and career growth, I’d advise looking elsewhere.

Cons: While Cisco provided a generous severance and treated layoffs with respect and dignity, the company’s periodic restructuring can create uncertainty. This cyclical approach to workforce changes makes me cautious about the long-term stability of a role there.

Pros:
- Great benefits
- Mostly competitive pay
- Decent opportunity for movement
- Fully remote
- Fantastic individual contributor culture
Cons:
Small stuff:
- Lots of meetings, but that's just remote tech life
- An already silo'd company feels extra silo'd when we are basically all remote
- Projects might not truly see the light of day, but that's the cold corporate world for you
- Can be hard to get converted from a contractor to a full-time employee

Big stuff:
- Executive leadership is ignorant of how people lower down the totem pole work. Or worse yet, they just don't care. Recent layoffs that hit the part of the company that had been meeting projections are laughable. All in the name of "optimizing for growth around AI"
- Layoffs are happening twice a year at this point. TWICE. And they aren't small either. The "always be hiring, always be firing" method feels terrifying to work under.
- Cisco is a dinosaur (old) company. I think their focus on AI will lead them nowhere since there's no way they can keep up with the more modern, agile tech companies.

Pros: Good benefits at the company level -- Birthday PTO, Low Insurance cost, Day for Me. Great opportunities to volunteer with your select organizations or local events if you have a local office in your city/state. You can choose latest laptop at onboarding
Cons: If you are a person who like to work in a modern collaborative team, e.g. Agile team with Sprint activities, especially demo/retro to give and receive feedback/recognition, this company may not be for you. The teams are usually driven by certain groups of people who have the invisible "authority" and "power". The work is busy, but it's because of the disorganized and non-feedback work. This is due to the nature of "solo" work, e.g. This guy A handles feature X and he usually the only "go-to" person for X, no matter if there may be some better approach or at least some chances for guy A to receive feedback. Guy A won't likely know (and may not have time to care) what the guy B is working on. Some partners (internal end users of our software) do not have technical background but like to use force you to do terrible work on their feedback

Pros: The initial compensation packages are generally good (though stock grants have been poor and you will have to leave the company to get a sizable pay raise).
Cons: It's a political nightmare mixed with a lot of DEI nonsense. Their glory years are behind them and all their major product lines are under attack by strong competitors. Some senior management is trying to change the company culture and fight back in the market by pushing Meraki to the front of the product line, but Meraki by itself is not an answer. The problems are deep and structural and they require knowledgeable, fearless leaders to make any progress. Unfortunately for Cisco, those are few and far between. I watched several good people try to make progress on substantial issues, all to have them generally fail. Most VPs have a relatively cushy job and are just milking the compensation package while Rome burns.

Pros: Used to be great place
Cons:
Internal to Cisco. Huge organisational restructuring every couple of years with redundancies. Has lost the way that made it great. 

Chaos has ensued during each restructuring. Several board level leaders have left. Last minute decisions and chop changing by ELT because of poor decisions and inability to keep to long term plans.

The phrase care deeply is coined by ELT. Almost verging on a brain washing and gas lighting process because the actions do not match:

Announcing redundancies, then waiting 4 weeks before starting. leaving employee in the dark and creating huge amounts of stress.

Middle managers and employees are being squeezed, creating a toxic workplace. Employees forced into the list below. Fearful of saying anything, due to the every 2 year redundancies:

	• Accept targets that are over 4 months late and repay commissions retroactively.
	•	Cover increased number of product lines, despite inadequate training on the new offerings.
	•	Meet significantly increased targets, sometimes 6x or more.
	•	Take on multiple roles due to ongoing layoffs over the past year.

• No voluntary redundancy so accept all the above or leave of your own accord. 
• No training program to re-skill talent into new growth areas. Would rather fire and hire.

No pay increase to reflect these additional responsibilities.

Pros: One of the most significant advantages of working at Cisco is the flexibility it offers. Whether you prefer to work from your home office, a co-working space, or even a beachside café, the company empowers you to choose your optimal working environment. Cons: One of the most pressing issues at Cisco is the frequent layoffs. While I understand that businesses must adapt to market conditions and make difficult decisions, the regularity of these firings has left many employees feeling anxious about their positions. This climate of uncertainty not only impacts individual performance but also hinders team cohesion and trust.

Pros:
Strong Brand Reputation: Cisco is a well-respected name in the tech industry, providing employees with a sense of pride and credibility.
Competitive Compensation and Benefits: Cisco typically offers competitive salaries, bonuses, and a comprehensive benefits package, including health insurance, retirement plans, and stock options.
Opportunities for Growth and Development: With its global presence and diverse product portfolio, Cisco provides ample opportunities for career advancement and professional development.
Collaborative Culture: Cisco often fosters a collaborative and inclusive work environment, encouraging teamwork and knowledge sharing.
Cutting-Edge Technology: Employees at Cisco have the chance to work with the latest technologies and innovations in the networking industry.
Work-Life Balance: Cisco often prioritizes work-life balance, offering flexible work arrangements and supportive policies.
Cons:
Bureaucracy and Slow Decision-Making: As a large corporation, Cisco can sometimes be characterized by bureaucracy and slow decision-making processes.
Frequent Organizational Changes: Due to the dynamic nature of the tech industry, Cisco may experience frequent organizational changes and restructuring.
High-Pressure Environment: Some roles within Cisco can be demanding and high-pressure, requiring employees to meet tight deadlines and handle complex projects.
Limited Job Security: While Cisco is a stable company, job security can never be guaranteed, especially in a rapidly evolving industry.

Pros: Work-life balance; true hybrid working style with options fully at employee's discretion; excellent fringe benefits.
Cons:
Has-been mentality. Innovation went stale some 10y ago. Working environment can be toxic in some groups. Over-the-top whitewashing with PR stunts like Best Place To Work, Sylicon Valley-style give-back-to-community volunteer porn initiatives, and thoughtless false-charity initiatives running amock (e.g. email-spamming and guilt-tripping over USD 0.1 donations), and other purely PR moves. Internal cultural issues go unaddressed. Lay-off process has become overly routine and de-humanised. Too adept at flaunting labour protections in each country of operation, with powerful law firms.
It's become a caricature. Fallen fowl to the profile in Le Management Totalitaire (Violaine Des Courières)

Pros:
* Cisco pays reasonably well for entry positions in my area
* Good support and patience for ramping up new grad hires
* Good culture inside teams, coworkers have always been pleasant to work with
* Work life balance has been good within my team
Cons:
* Most testing is done in India, meaning there is poor overlap in working hours which hurts productivity
* We are heavily pushed to use internally developed tools that end up losing support without any viable alternative in place which leaves teams maintaining it for themselves
* Typical tech company "we're prioritizing AI" without any clarity of what that means
* Constant layoffs hurt morale, especially given the dissonance of huge acquisitions like Splunk
* Between layoffs and turnover, teams are understaffed for the work expected
* Far too many "hurry up and wait" moments in development
* Pay raises do not occur fast enough or at a rate high enough retain good staff
* Management is poor at recognizing problems (refusing to admit how far we are behind competitors, acting like the customers are wrong), but even when they do recognize an issue no solutions are proposed

Cons: Bureaucracy Red Tape Preventing Sales Progression

Pros: Cisco is known for its robust culture of innovation and professional development, offering employees opportunities to work with cutting-edge technologies in networking, cloud, and cybersecurity. The company fosters a collaborative environment with extensive resources for learning and career advancement, as well as strong mentorship programs and a commitment to employee well-being. Many employees appreciate Cisco’s focus on work-life balance, flexible work arrangements, and inclusive culture, which can make it an appealing workplace for those seeking stability and growth in the tech industry.
Cons: As a large, global corporation, Cisco’s size can sometimes mean that navigating internal processes and decision-making can be slow, with layers of bureaucracy that may delay project approvals or adaptability to change. This structure may feel limiting for employees who prefer a more agile, startup-like environment. Additionally, some teams can experience a high level of demand and fast-paced work, which may occasionally impact work-life balance depending on the project and department.

Pros:
* Salary and other benefits are industry leading
* Work-life balance can be as comfortable as you need it to be
* Ability to use work time to volunteer within the community is fantastic
* Large variety or products to work on with some internal mobility opportunities
* Great place to learn how things work in a 'real' company with exposure to many groups and functions
Cons:
* Slow. It's a large corporate with more processes & policies than people.
* The leadership team is too politically correct - always trying to say the 'right thing' so as not to upset anyone. Sadly. this has the opposite effect than is intended. There are multiple groups within the company actively hostile towards others.
* The long term strategies never seem to work, since every 1-2 years there is 'another restructuring' and the share price simply stagnates
* Many products & processes are still hardware focused - don't come here looking for a fast-pased innovative environment (it might exist in small parts of Cisco, but it's not the overall culture)

Cons:
If you have followed the news over the last year, you probably saw that Cisco has had many layoffs in the last 12 months. At least 3 that I am aware of. New hires are often chosen for this because they are largely more replaceable than engineers that have been there for 10+ years and are local experts that would be very hard to replace. So I would advise against hiring into this company until its internal business issues have settled out. 
Work/life balance is also very hit or miss, but thats a lot of tech these days.

Pros:
1.	Industry Leader: Cisco is a well-established leader in networking and IT, providing TEMs with the opportunity to work with cutting-edge technologies and solutions.
	2.	Professional Growth: Cisco offers extensive training and development programs, which can help TEMs stay updated with the latest industry trends and enhance their technical and soft skills.
	3.	Global Network: Working for Cisco provides the opportunity to engage with a global client base and collaborate with diverse teams across the world.
	4.	Career Advancement: Cisco’s size and global presence offer multiple career paths, allowing TEMs to move into different roles, whether it’s more technical, managerial, or customer-focused.
	5.	Strong Brand: Being associated with Cisco can be a significant professional asset, as it is a recognized and respected brand in the technology industry.
	6.	Comprehensive Benefits: Cisco is known for its competitive compensation packages, including health benefits, retirement plans, and other employee perks like work-life balance initiatives.
	7.	Innovation: TEMs at Cisco have the opportunity to work on innovative projects, which can be both challenging and rewarding, allowing them to contribute to transformative technologies.
Cons: Frequent Changes: Cisco’s dynamic environment, including reorganizations or shifts in strategy, can create uncertainty and require TEMs to adapt quickly to new directives.

Pros: Good salary and benefits. You might get a good manager for a short time, but they will inevitably leave or get pushed out.
Cons:
Blatantly discriminate against older (e.g., over 40 years old) workers.
Lots of churn and re-orgs. If you join a non-toxic group with a good manager - that could change in a matter of months.
Lots of tribalism and fiefdoms - good luck if your role is trying to get different groups or even different BUs to collaborate - most Ciscoians have blinders on and can't see what's best for the company as a whole nor their customers. 
Got rid of accumulated PTO.
Constant layoffs that are not performance related. You can get an exemplary performance review and huge bonus one year and get laid off the next with the same level of performance and output.

Pros:
-) In general Cisco is a good employer, the company is well functioning, team play and team spirit are factors highly valued within the organization
-) Performance of the company is on the outside (share price) good, employees benefit of the increasing share price due to RSU and employee share purchase programs
-) Future proof acquisitions have been made with Splunk
-) Payment and remuneration packages are well compared to average incomes and within the IT industry (all of IT)
Cons:
-) 2023/24 were difficult years, lay offs were not well communicated by top management, which pushed motivation of staff down
-) Payment and remuneration packages are in direct peer comparison to other, leading IT companies rather below what others pay
-) Inflation of the last years (2020-2024) was not addressed by the company, incomes have lost up to 20% of net-purchase value over these years. To date there is no communication from management how to deal with this

Pros: This has been the best job I’ve ever had. Great salary and benefits, I have an amazing team, and I personally see my impact across the company. These are all great qualities and why I would never want to leave. I could retire here…. But see cons.
Cons:
It is a layoff culture. “Cognitive dissonance” are the two words employees should note as leadership fails to respect us in words what their behavior is communicating (see cisco’s response on 12/9, “committed to retaining talent” (paraphrased). It’s simply not true by their actions.

I think in the past four years I have experienced six layoffs and so far survived them all. The reality though is that we always know these layoffs are around the corner, and when the news is leaked (which it always is) people freak out (understandably!). Our last layoff required three+ months of not knowing who would have a job—that’s not going to help our bottom line (but I think is tied to a regulation). 

Though, root cause is not the timeline. It’s the layoff and (I think unintentional) dishonesty that kills me and has me in a bind—I love this company, but my stress can’t handle this company. I have a family to feed. 

Also, leadership is a bit out of touch. In the last layoff they remarked the percentage cut they would receive in bonus, which still resulted in multi million salaries (which was commented on in the chat as it happened, with the receipts… ouch!). That’s not consolation for the person who relies on their check to stay housed and feed their family, especially in this oversaturated market.

Pros:
Cisco has been an excellent place to work, especially when it comes to maintaining a healthy work-life balance. Here are some specific points that highlight my experience:

Flexible Working Hours:
The company offers flexible working hours, which has been a significant benefit. Employees are allowed to start and finish their workdays at times that suit their personal schedules, as long as they meet project deadlines and attend necessary meetings.

Remote Work Options:
Since the pandemic, Cisco has adopted a hybrid work model. Employees have the option to work from home several days a week, which greatly reduces commuting time and allows for a more comfortable and productive work environment.

Vacation and Time Off:
The company provides generous vacation days and encourages employees to use them. I never felt pressured to skip my vacations, and management genuinely supports taking time off to recharge.

Health and Wellness Programs:
Cisco offers various health and wellness programs, including gym memberships, yoga classes, and mental health resources. These programs are a testament to the company's commitment to the well-being of its employees.

Pros:
Great Learning Opportunities: Cisco is a leader in networking and communication technologies. Working there can provide you with exposure to cutting-edge technologies and opportunities for professional growth.
Strong Brand and Reputation: Cisco is a well-known company with a strong reputation in the tech industry. Working there can enhance your resume and open doors to future career opportunities.
Competitive Compensation and Benefits: Cisco offers competitive salaries and benefits packages, including health insurance, retirement plans, and more.
Work-Life Balance: While this can vary depending on the team and project, Cisco generally values work-life balance, offering flexible work arrangements and support for employees' well-being.
Global Opportunities: Cisco is a global company with offices around the world. Working there can provide you with opportunities to work in different countries and experience different cultures.
Cons:
arge Organization: Cisco is a large organization, which can sometimes lead to bureaucracy and slow decision-making processes.
High Expectations: Cisco is a fast-paced and innovative company, which means that the expectations for performance can be high, leading to pressure to deliver results quickly.
Job Insecurity: Like any large company, Cisco's business is subject to market fluctuations and changes in technology trends, which can lead to job insecurity during times of economic uncertainty.
Limited Career Growth: While Cisco offers great learning opportunities, some employees may find that career advancement is limited due to the hierarchical nature of the organization.
Workload: Depending on the team and project, the workload at Cisco can be demanding, requiring long hours and tight deadlines.

Pros:
- **Innovative Environment**: Work with cutting-edge technology and be part of a leading company in networking and cybersecurity.
- **Career Growth**: Opportunities for continuous learning, development, and advancement within the company.
- **Work-Life Balance**: Flexible work options, including remote work and comprehensive wellness programs.
- **Inclusive Culture**: Commitment to diversity, equity, and inclusion with various employee resource groups.
- **Global Impact**: Engage in projects that influence businesses and communities worldwide.
- **Comprehensive Benefits**: Competitive salaries, health insurance, retirement plans, and other employee benefits.
- **Corporate Social Responsibility**: Involvement in sustainable practices and community-focused initiatives.
Cons:
- **Large Organization**: Navigating a big corporate structure can be challenging and slow decision-making processes.
- **High Expectations**: High performance standards and workload can lead to stress and burnout.
- **Frequent Changes**: Regular organizational changes and restructuring can create uncertainty.
- **Competition for Advancement**: Intense competition for promotions and career growth opportunities.
- **Work-Life Balance Variability**: Work-life balance can vary greatly depending on the role and department.
- **Bureaucracy**: Potential for bureaucratic red tape which can hinder agility and innovation.

Pros: I joined one of the fastest-growing teams at the company less than five years ago. It was a lot of fun and I felt respected by my leader and peers.
Cons: Fast forward to late 2023, when everything began to unravel. Literally everyone on our team is gone now, most of us due to reductions in force. Morale is at an all-time low. Executive leadership has made bad hires of abusive senior leaders and made massive acquisitions (instead of innovating) and we all paid the price. If you're looking for stability and fulfillment, look elsewhere.

Pros: The benefits of working at Cisco are what keeps people in seat. Great healthcare, great stock options, great wfh atmosphere. The many different products that Cisco makes allows for account managers to hit their goal from one of their many product lines. The products that Cisco makes are phenomenal.
Cons: As a sales rep, you really have no control over what territory you cover, and what accounts you have this year to next. If you are not Enterprise sales rep, you could spend the entire year trying to develop a relationship with an account, only to find out that you no longer cover it when the new fiscal comes around. The goals drastically change, with no warrant to why or how they came up with this number. Finance also will regoal you and keep all your money. Mid-level management also has little to no control or say into how things are managed or done. Cisco sells against itself. Some products compete with each other, as well as some of the programs like NFR give products away.

- Products are getting worse and we have less and less resources to support technically
- Consistent layoffs have demoralized the company while the ELT keeps making millions a year and have failed us as a company, but take no responsibility

That person takes the baton to talk about whatever jargon the company is into at the moment without making any differences. Then cutting people, I think there were 3 or 4 rounds of layoffs when I was in. It's hard to take a company series, "we have awesome culture" when you position is like russian roulette.

Pros: Cisco lives up to a lot of their promises and top level leadership leads by example in encouraging their values. Cisco provides a lot of resources and opportunities to explore what you uniquely bring to your work, lead with your strengths, practice mindfulness, and keep balance and flexibility in your life. It is a place that strives to be welcoming and supportive of diverse communities with a lot of employee resource groups to help. Their benefits are great and receiving 80 hrs per year to volunteer is simply amazing. I hope they don't cut that back.
Cons:
The PTO is 20 days per year, but you are forced to use 3-4 for those days during the mandatory holiday shutdown period, so the PTO is effectively 16 or 17 days. 
They have had a lot of unannounced layoffs or "restructuring" since I joined.
And like any large corporation, a lot of the internal processes and requirements are like navigating a maze to follow. 
It is also very slow to move and coming from an acquisition this was a hard transition. Also, when we were acquired, we thought we would get more resources to help, but that was not the case. 
Despite the ideals for how to be a good leader and make Cisco a great place to work, individual managers may or may not follow, leaving much variability in the working environment on a particular team.

Pros:
I was one of the apprentices for the Technical Consulting Engineer role. During the first two months as an Apprentice, Cisco has an organization and specialized team that prepares you for the role of a Technical Consulting Engineer, and to be honest they do a great job at it. 

Then you are placed into a team within the 5 specialized areas in TAC: Service Provider, Enterprise, Security, Datacenter, and Collaboration. Each of these areas have specific teams and you start to train in those specific technologies and slowly start taking cases of increasing difficulty on the mentorship of more senior engineer. My experience was good, however an individual's experience will depend upon the team that they arrive at.
Cons: Unfortunately, due to business circumstances and mismanagement I arrived to a team that didn't have business need for more employees and later on Cisco had to let me and many others go despite my boss and teammates being very satisfied with my performance.

1. Work-Life Balance: Cisco offers flexible working hours and the ability to work from home, which greatly helps in maintaining a good work-life balance.
2. Innovative Culture: The company encourages innovation and staying ahead with cutting-edge technology. Employees are often involved in impactful projects that shape the future of networking and communication.
3. Learning and Development: There are numerous opportunities for professional growth through training programs, certifications, and internal mobility.
4. Diversity and Inclusion: Cisco has a strong commitment to diversity and inclusion, fostering an environment where all employees feel valued and respected.
5. Supportive Management: Managers are generally supportive and open to feedback, helping employees reach their full potential.
Employee Benefits: Comprehensive benefits package including health insurance, retirement plans, and generous vacation time.

Cons:
Back to laying off every 6 months. The most likely reason you will get laid off is "this year's executive" for your function wants to do things differently. Or your team is marooned in the wrong organization. How did your team get marooned? From last year's executive's re-org. Being re-orged into IT or Operations is a common death sentence and you should begin a 6 month exit plan as soon as it happens.

Leadership couldn't answer a "How to return to growth?" question after the most recent layoff. CEO had a "hope in 6 months" answer. Services EVP had a word salad. This was a seeded question in a moderated forum. Newly appointed Chief Product Officer is coming from a lackluster division (WebEx) and admitted to knowing nothing about Enterprise Networking.

At this point, Cisco cannot attract innovative leaders or technical talent to reverse downward spiral.

Pros: It's a rare Silicon Valley tech company which is made up of grown-ups. Also, technology keeps changing, and Cisco's portfolio is broad enough that there's always some part of the company that's leading the way in its own area.
Cons: I love the quarterly "day for me" holidays, but I really, REALLY dislike the forced PTO days at Christmas and this year, at 4th of July too.

Pros: Supports diversity in its workforce
Cons: The company mandates the use of 8 out of 20 annual PTO days during fixed shutdowns in the holiday season and around July 4th, leaving only 12 days at the employee's discretion. Tenure doesn't increase PTO, with all employees capped at 20 days, which likely differs from executive privileges. Additionally, employees who relocate, even to areas with similar living costs, may face salary cuts under the guise of regional fairness, potentially impacting their finances significantly. This policy seems to prioritize the company's financial interests over employee well-being.

Pros: Cisco Systems Bangalore offers an exceptional employment experience. The company provides diverse opportunities, competitive compensation packages, and a stellar work culture. It fosters personal and professional growth for all employees, from entry-level to seasoned professionals. The compensation includes competitive salaries, comprehensive benefits, and performance-based incentives. Cisco's inclusive work environment encourages innovation and collaboration, with approachable leadership and a strong commitment to diversity. The company's dedication to work-life balance and community engagement initiatives further enhance its appeal. I highly recommend Cisco Systems Bangalore to anyone seeking a rewarding career in the tech industry.
Cons: My experience at Cisco Systems has been mixed. While the company offers technological innovation and opportunities, job security is a concern due to periodic layoffs. Frequent team reorganizations disrupt workflow and hinder relationship building. Additionally, the commitment to long-term employee growth can seem inconsistent. Prospective employees should weigh these challenges alongside the company's strengths before considering joining.

Pros:
- Cisco is the worldwide leader in technology that powers the Internet.
- 98% of employees at Cisco say it is a great place to work compared to 57% of employees at a typical U.S.-based company.
- When you join the company, you are made to feel welcome.
- Management is honest and ethical in its business practices.
- I am able to take time off from work when I think it's necessary.
- I am treated as a full member here regardless of my position.
- #1 in Best Workplaces for Parents™ 2023 (Large)
- #3 in Fortune Best Workplaces for Women™ 2023 (Large)
- #1 in Fortune Best Workplaces in Technology™ 2023 (Large)
- #1 in 2023 PEOPLE® Companies that Care
- #1 in Fortune Best Workplaces for Millennials™ 2023 (Large)
- #1 in Fortune 100 Best Companies to Work For® 2023
Cons: -To move up within the company you must have a good network of contacts, mentors and sponsors. And only you can create that network, no one will create it for you.

Pros: The company makes every effort to be employee focused. When teams are acquired, they are minimally modified to preserve what made them successful. Employees are diverse from all over the world. Bonuses are fair, time off is frequent, and HR resources are plentiful. I picked this company because it was rated so well in employee satisfaction, and it really shows.
Cons: Big companies have large priorities that may not always align with each employee, but the leadership still hosts regular Q & A sessions to assuage worries. Even during layoffs, the company did their best to help employees land on their feet with generous compensation (other companies escort employees out and abandon them).

Pros: Working at Cisco offers a dynamic and innovative environment, fostering professional growth through cutting-edge technology and industry-leading projects. Employees benefit from a culture that prioritizes work-life balance, diversity, and inclusion. Cisco’s commitment to continuous learning and development, along with competitive compensation and comprehensive benefits, makes it an excellent place to build a rewarding career.
Cons: A potential con of working at Cisco is that the large, corporate environment can sometimes lead to bureaucratic processes and slower decision-making. Navigating through multiple layers of management and adhering to extensive protocols may occasionally hinder agility and rapid innovation.

Pros:
Technological Leadership: Working at Cisco means being at the forefront of networking equipment and solutions, offering the chance to engage with cutting-edge technologies.
Professional Development: The company provides extensive learning resources and training programs, encouraging employee growth and advancement.
Strong Corporate Culture: Cisco emphasizes diversity and inclusivity, creating a supportive and respectful work environment.
Flexible Work Arrangements: Support for remote work and flexible schedules helps employees achieve a balance between work and life.
Cons:
Bureaucratic Systems: As a large corporation, decision-making can be slow, and there is a noticeable presence of bureaucratic processes.
Market Competition Pressures: With increasing market competition, Cisco faces challenges from emerging competitors, leading to stress and uncertainty in the workplace.
Frequent Restructuring: The company has undergone several restructurings and business adjustments, which can lead to feelings of uncertainty about career progression.
Innovation Challenges: Although Cisco is committed to innovation, maintaining a leading position in the rapidly evolving tech landscape is an ongoing challenge.

Have worked at another company since leaving and realized how well Cisco takes care of their employees.  Current employees should be very thankful because the grass is definitely not greener on the other side.
Cons: The area the company needs to focus on is laying off the employees who are not performing or are on performance improvement plans.  I saw a lot of very talented and intelligent employees with proven track records get impacted by the layoffs and noticed the under performing employees are still there.  They also need to spend some time focusing on the international employees as well.  I worked with a lot of international folks who were not performing but managed to not be impacted by the layoffs due to country laws.  The company really needs to take a closer look at that as well.

Pros:
The culture is very remote-friendly, with all teams spread out practically world-wide. 
There is a large amount of effort spent on developing and reinforcing an inclusive culture. 
Engineering used to have the final say on everything but sales and marketing are getting to have more input, to the benefit of customers.
Cons:
In the current push to merge all the previous acquisitions together with the main portfolio it often appears that there is preferential treatment for people from the same group as the person who ends up in the leadership role of the merged team.
Also, many leadership vacancies are being filled by white men, and the gender gap in leadership is widening.

Pros: Large company with resources to potentially do some creative, impactful work
Cons:
Can be competitive in an unhealthy way; toxic
Saw numerous people let go/laid off who were excellent employees who had dedicated themselves to Cisco and were well-liked and respected by peers and/or direct reports. This had a very negative effect on employee morale and created a toxic employee culture.
Some senior-level execs have an ivory tower attitude - unapproachable and coddled/spoiled (not the roll-up-your-sleeves, can-do, dig deep attitude that once made Cisco great)
Seems like everyone thinks their product or solution is the next big thing -- too much drinking the Kool-Aid and not a grasp on the reality facing them in the marketplace
Not enough post-mortem analysis -- lots of repeat mistakes and inefficient work styles; over-emphasis on post launch slide deck for execs with inflated metrics that disguised truth of inefficient, toxic work style and culture.

Pros: Great benefits, inclusive culture, great brand recognition, matrixed organization, and relatively good compensation. There's a reason people come to Cisco and never leave, it's a company built by good people.
Cons:
Do-nothing middle management, obsession with forecasting to the detriment of customer engagement, age bias toward Gen X and above for leadership which is stifling innovation and change. 

Recent influence from Palo Alto Networks refugees and Cisco outsiders are destroying what made Cisco different from peers in the industry - good culture. Three days a week centered on obsessively detailed metrics, overly rigid sales processes that destroy authenticity and creativity, fear-based sales culture around performance. There's also an unspoken but obvious effort to undermine longer term Cisco sellers with mercenary hires from outside the company that have no IT background whatsoever. New external leadership hires are telling partners that "Cisco salespeople are lazy". 

New sales leader is toxic and clueless about technology, reads from a script, does not understand what customers expect from a mature technology company like Cisco, and is inundating our sales force with administrative overhead that makes AMs/PSSs feel more like accountants. This is couched in a new mantra around "creating a unified sales process", but is bogging down sellers with hours upon hours of onerous training and administrative work.

Pros: Everyone I interacted with was friendly, helpful, and professional. Although management pushed for hybrid working from what was previously full remote, it was a 'come at your own time' culture so long as you met your responsibilities. Break room had a fancy coffee machine, and management would cater lunches once a week. Most days I would come into the office to do any work that needed hands on configuration of our testbed in the lab, grab lunch, then continue to work from home.
Cons: Well I was laid off after 6 months so obviously layoffs. The late night or early morning meetings to catch up with the India team was tiresome. An incredible breadth of information you have to have a working knowledge of. Every protocol, the custom OS's and commands on the devices, and how to work with Cisco proprietary systems like SD-WAN. You have to learn the CLI commands before you can move onto GUI since you can't accomplish many things with a GUI alone. Personally, my manager was outright adversarial with me as a junior. I was put under the wing of 3 different people in trying to acclimate to the job, it was highly stressful trying to get up to speed. Few transferable skills: I worked with an python library that was eventually made open source, but there wasn't too much documentation and few employers care about my experience with a library that's solely used to test networks.

Pros: Working at Cisco offers opportunities to work for a global technology leader, engage in innovative projects, and access career development programs. A diverse, collaborative workforce, competitive compensation, and work-life balance make it an attractive choice. Cisco's commitment to corporate responsibility and employee well-being further enhance its appeal.
Cons: While working at Cisco has its advantages, there are some potential cons to consider: 1. Large Organization: Cisco is a large corporation, which may lead to bureaucracy and slower decision-making processes. 2. Competitive Environment: The tech industry is highly competitive, which can result in pressure to meet performance targets. 3. Job Stability: Like many tech companies, Cisco's workforce may face job instability due to market fluctuations. 4. Workload: Some employees may experience high workloads and long hours, impacting work-life balance. 5. Location: Job locations can vary, and some positions may require relocation. 6. Changing Technologies: The fast-paced tech industry may demand constant adaptation to new technologies and skills. 7. Office Politics: As with any large organization, office politics and hierarchies can sometimes be challenging.

Pros: Great culture, and incredible talent. Benefits are top-notch.
Cons: The annual mass layoff to right the mothership is always a difficult event. You are either a member of the RIF team, or your workload likely just doubled. With all of the acquisitions, Cisco makes each year, they need to maintain balance with the headcount. Rather than lay off all the talent from the newly acquired companies, they dig deep into their existing labor force. It's a way of life and Cisco.

Pros:
Above average compensation.
It used to be the culture.... hopefully it can be recessitated.
Cons:
Culture is decaying with growing pockets of toxic teams. Leadership that is being promoted have either made a pledge of loyalty to the leadership above or they are a "yes Sir" kind of person. So, it has become a norm to see toxic VPs that did not make it to their positions based on merit and see them openly exhibit some of the most outrageously toxic behaviors (condescending, see differing opinions as "falling out of line", etc.). This leads to most of the Director level being disempowered and having to balance self preservation with doing the right thing for the business & the employees. The remaining layers of management are each less empowered than the layer above them. This leads to individual contributors that are struggling to contribute because navigating the trickling down toxicity is consuming most of their time and mental cycles. 
The problem is not limited to VP and below. It start with the glaring void of a Head of Engineering in the C-Suite. Each Business Unit Head reports to the CEO - thus making the CEO the one to lead technology direction, prioritizations and the biggest one: getting the BUs to work together to deliver on a platform strategy. That would be great if Chuck was Elon or Jeff B. - but he is not. So, he has outsourced those decisions to be based on C-Suite consensus - the very reason why the C-Suite has resorted to running like the Senate - alliances, lobbying, trading favors, etc. Oh, and the CFO ... he runs the financials like an accountant - I bet Cisco's books have never looked better :-). But top talent is walking to the competition, moral is at an all time low, and innovation (through acquisition, "Spin In" , or internal investments) is at a stand still since Kelly left. But I bet those books look good :-). BTW, Splunk does not qualify as "innovation infusion". There are plenty of "innovation" activities talked about by BU leader turned Chief Strategy Officer (who still cannot get herself to fully perform the CSO role because she has not let go of her BU leader identity - so, she is the CSO but also leads Applications *shake head*). Activities only - no results - no successful monetization. It does not take much to understand why innovation is dead, the culture has turned highly political and toxic, and now business performance is impacted (it's not just due to macroeconomic). It is sad to see such a great company deteriorate at such a rapid pace. It's making it obvious that the #1 Place to Work ranking is a paid PR service. However, I do have to say that out of the entire C-Suite, Fran is the only executive that is delivering results (you may not like or agree with the results or approach but she is delivering). 
What is the CEO succession plan (as Chuck is in semi-retirement mode and focused on building personal legacy/brand vs running a company)?
What is the board thinking & doing??? Fiduciary duty anyone?

Pros: Great company to use a stepping stone for a better job outside! Other Pros: RSUs are good, ESPP is standard, company has a diverse product portfolio that is potentially well-suited for economic challenges, senior management seems okay *I haven't paid too much attention to them* Honestly, I do truly believe that Cisco has the potential to be a great company that is able to attract top talent in Silicon Valley. However, the company needs to reevaluate middle management. Investing in management training is the bare minimum and they're currently are doing that, but the company really needs to do more. For example, promoting individuals based on their leadership qualities and not just their technical knowledge and years of experience. Cultivating a more progressive and open-minded culture could go a long way in improving employee satisfaction and retention.
Cons: Disappointed by: dental and vision options, have to pay to use company gym, a lot of teams are starting to require "return to office" which is going to hurt the company as they are also trying to downsize their real estate, poor laptop options if you need a non-MacBook. Please take all high ratings and company awards lightly, as Cisco does push it's current employees to skew the results. Additionally, I've seen many younger individuals leave due to unhappiness which does not get reflect in any reviews.

Pros: Fully remote, flexible, free online courses, networking opportunities, fair compensation, good severance I want to say opportunities for career growth, but I haven't heard any successful stories from my peers so far except promotions within the same team/organization. At least in the organization I work, many people are here to just coast, so if you want to grow and get experience, you have to be proactive and patient to make the best use of your time.
Cons: I worked with some of the worst people. They were arrogant, emotionally immature, overly defensive, and surprisingly incompetent / out of touch - maybe byproducts of the coasting culture? I also worked with people who were highly capable and professional, so it might've been just a bad luck. Heavy layers of professional middle managers. Constant restructuring (aka layoff) ordered by the leadership who doesn't understand what's happening in the field and things are generally messy because of that. There are huge gaps between the US office and regional offices which is normal for Gaishi (foreign-affiliated companies), but it can be frustrating.

It has been years since our engineering org has been fully staffed. Since 2021, they have been provided less and less backfill and no real new headcount for engineering while creating more and more features to support and fix but not having any people to actually support and fix them. Additionally, they took away most of our travel and education benefits, which helped balance out the lean compensation years.

Pros: Flexibility. This job is very flexible. Work-Life balance is extraordinary. To the point where most of us work 15 hours a week or less, or from the car. Health, 401k Benefits are great.
Cons: Diversity and Inclusion is the highest priority in the company. Some might see this as a Pro, but let me explain. Unqualified people have been shuffled around the company into leadership roles during and after COVID, some have grown to be successful, while many have failed completely, which casacades and causes multiple leadership failures down to the engineers. Many great engineers have left due to the failures of our recently promoted leadership. ESG is such a high focus that our products are failing simple quality checks. We have had many customers leave Cisco products for Palo Alto or other vendors simply because our products are garbage now, and the TAC support is atrocious. Be prepared for an annual layoff here, generally every year there is a fat trimming movement where useless roles are removed, allowing the folks to transfer to other parts of the company, where they are utterly useless. Customer Experience is a nightmare., where the Customer is put 2nd, and profits are put 1st. CX BCS contracts are the worst thing for delivery - nonsense deliverables that the customer does not have any desire for. It's purely a moneygrab by Cisco

Pros: My experience at Cisco has been nothing short of exceptional. Cisco is full of highly skilled professionals with whom I had the pleasure of collaborating. The company also provides ample opportunities for technical and personal growth through its diverse range of training programs. But make sure you land in a team with a remarkable leader. This key for ensuring an enjoyable experience while working at Cisco.
Cons: Several divisions within Cisco suffer from a toxic work environment, primarily due to inadequate management practices that seem to derive satisfaction from causing employees misery. It is concerning to note that some divisions have a minimal representation of female staff. A significant aspect of Cisco's culture is centered around showcasing achievements that lack substance, leading to a wasteful expenditure of time in repetitive meetings and activities focused on reinventing the wheel. Additionally, numerous teams perform overlapping tasks that fail to provide any tangible value to the organisation. The Business Unit is particularly unproductive, operating reactively instead of proactively to address problems.

Pros: Cisco gives you 2 months to find another position within the company if they laid you off.

Pros: Good PTO (~3 weeks) plus holidays and random Days for Me, WFH flexibility, performance-based financial incentives via bonuses and peer-to-peer recognition, company is very engaged in creating positive company culture, have had excellent experiences within the PRIDE and LGBTQIA+ communities, good focus on career growth and growing within Cisco, tons of opportunities for international and cross-cultural collaboration across teams.
Cons: Sales still suffers from 80s corporate nastiness occasionally; standard big-company red tape; depending on your department, VPs/directors can be very out of touch with the day-to-day business until something negative gets their attention. I also fear we're moving towards an employment model where too many of the managers are doing the work of 2 people, stretching them far too thin.

Pros: * So many smart people work here and no one is a jerk (so rare for tech) * "Be kinder than necessary" is honestly the way the culture feels - it's not just a Duo slogan * So much diversity and true respect for differences in all areas * Individual contributors have a ton of agency, most companies of this size usually only give execs that kind of power * The entire company shuts down over the Christmas/New Year holidays which means we all get a break * Senior leadership is focused on the right things and is pretty transparent and communicates regularly * Compensation is competitive w/market
Cons: * As a sales-driven org, the urge to 'sell' or market products too early puts customer trust at risk

Pros:
Cisco is a great company and a great place to work. I have been there for more than 22 years and I do not regret a single year I spend there. 
Company staff & culture are aligned with people who are open minded, highly motivated and willing to give 150%, but on the same note the company kept the stress level on a still moderate level. The remuneration packages are in accordance to what you will be asked to deliver and are usually above the norm, so you will get compensated for the extra mile. What is appreciated is that there are nearly no real jerks around in Cisco.
Cons: Over the last years (2022 and 2023) the company tends to build up too high stress in sales on the numbers. Cisco was always on the numbers, but not too pushy neither. Too much push delegated to the sales/account manager level can reach a tipping point where people lose the motivation. This is to be observed critical over the next year(s) to come, Cisco would lose a lot culture wise if they continue on that path,

Pros: I left the company and came back. The culture is work hard/play hard, coworkers are supportive, and the overall feel is positive for me. I don't dread coming to work (which is in my home office now) like I have at other companies. Great benefits, great PTO policy, great extended team members and helpful coworkers. I enjoy selling Cisco products.
Cons: I left Cisco due to changes that happened on my team and an overall feeling of "is the grass greener?" It wasn't greener because I'm back at Cisco. The issues of working in a large company can be frustrating. Things can move slowly, processes can be cumbersome, but I'll take that over a work-obsessed careless culture like many companies seem to have these days.

Pros: Great company culture 90% of folks are on the same page Very transparent on all levels The best benefits and perks I've experienced Your team has your back Managers have a mindset of working for and supporting their team PTO accrual and approval is the easiest ever You can take PTO whenever you need it Time to give is a great volunteering time offered by Cisco for us to engage in community work, who even does that!! This is awesome! The CEO Chuck Robbins and the ETL team is simply amazing and they listen An over all autonomy of work is practiced Great work like balance and it is encouraged if you happen to be a workaholic. Overall comradery still exists in Cisco, Cisconians actually care for each other.
Cons: The work can sometimes have longer time lines due to processes being in place and it may seem like a slow moving ship sometimes, at the same time processes mean consistency and hassle free audits in the larger scheme of things. The salaries are market average however there are so many other factors that out weight the salary aspect.

Pros:
Definitely one of the best companies to work for in terms of work life balance. Atleast it’s true in terms of the team I worked for in Bangalore. 
Was extremely lucky to have had amazing managers.
Cons:
Work was ok initially as a young engineer I got to learn a lot, but as you grow in your career as an SDE your opportunities to learn kinda reduces as you have a lot of senior folk around and you might not end up getting your due recognition and opportunities.

Promotions are difficult as you grow can be said the same for other companies.

Salary hikes are mediocre reasons being budget constraints but company has the budget to spend billions to buy Splunk

Opportunities to switch to a team in US usually gets shot down by pathetic Executives in the US and India. Even if the other team really likes you and wants you there. Basically favourites of those people might get a chance in the future if an opportunity presents itself.

Overall salary compared to other major companies in the market it’s below the market average. I’ve seen smaller and bigger companies who were willing to offer close to 40LPA for the same role.

Lots of reorgs and uncertainty, priorities keep changing and most recently in our team one person had to do 2-3 people’s work would have been valuable if the work was something cutting edge but it basic UI work and some simple backend services to setup simple API routes to serve content to the UI. Definitely got bored and burnt out quite fast.
