Pros: Where do I start? At Cisco we have a fantastic culture, I'm encouraged to bring my whole self to work as the company cherish diversity, inclusion and the different perspectives we all bring. It's a company that takes good care of their employees, that encourages work/life balance and has the best benefits. I have the day off on my birthday, 10 days a year to do volunteer work, an extra week of holiday fully paid, endless opportunities for stretch assignments, courses on personal development and access to mentors / coaches to mention a few. Cisco is a company that makes you work hard but they thank you for it, they pay well and stocks and bonuses are great. In addition, I'm surrounded by hard-working talented, intelligent and kind colleagues that has my back.
Cons: Hard to transition to new roles

Pros:
-Extremely supportive coworkers (the most helpful people I know)
-The benefits are amazing - not just 401K/PTO/Health Insurance, but Cisco has so many continued learning events and resources, 5 days VTO (volunteer time off) to give back, employee resource organizations to get involved with, on site gym (with awesome classes) and healthcare facilities, plus a lot of on-site events to promote cross-collaboration with other groups. 
- The pay is amazing.
- Very communicative and transparent with all changes/considerations. We have monthly All-Hands via Cisco TV where our CEO and much of the C-Suite are updating us on the latest happenings in the company.
- Very supportive leadership in ensuring you are set up for success and continually helping you to identify and plan for future roles you may want to take on.
Cons:
- The commute/traffic to RTP.
- Like many large companies, there are a lot of old tools, processes, and systems that you have to use to do your job. They are working hard to consolidate them though! 
- Again, with many other large companies, lay offs can happen (but Cisco did put on an internal career fair the last time for those being displaced to try and refill open positions based on skillsets of those that were impacted.)

Pros: 1. Healthcare Benefits: Medical Insurance: Comprehensive medical coverage for employees and their dependents. Dental and Vision Insurance: Coverage for dental and vision care expenses. Mental Health Support: Access to counseling and mental health services. 2. Financial Benefits: Stock Options: Stock options or grants to allow employees to share in the company’s success. Employee Stock Purchase Plan (ESPP): Allows employees to purchase Cisco stock at a discounted price. Financial Counseling: Financial planning and counseling services. 3. Work-Life Balance: Paid Time Off (PTO): Vacation, holidays, and paid time off benefits. Flexible Work Hours: Flexible work schedules and options for remote work. Parental Leave: Paid time off for new parents, including maternity and paternity leave. Sabbatical Leave: Opportunities for extended time off after a certain number of years of service. 4. Career Development: Training and Development: Access to training programs and resources to enhance skills and knowledge. Tuition Assistance: Financial support for employees pursuing further education or professional development. Career Counseling: Guidance for career development and advancement within the company. 5. Health and Wellness: Wellness Programs: Programs and resources to promote employee health and well-being. Fitness Benefits: Gym memberships or fitness-related reimbursements. Health Screenings: Regular health check-ups and screenings. 6. Employee Assistance Programs (EAP): Counseling Services: Confidential counseling and support services for personal and work-related issues. Legal and Financial Consultations: Access to legal and financial advice. 7. Other Perks: Employee Discounts: Discounts on Cisco products and services. Transportation Benefits: Commuter benefits, transportation subsidies, or parking discounts. Social and Recreational Activities: Company-sponsored events and activities for employees and their families.
Cons: 1. Unequal Distribution: Depending on the hierarchical structure, higher-ranking employees might have access to significantly better benefits than lower-ranking employees, leading to disparities within the workforce. 2. Global Disparities: Benefits can vary significantly between Cisco employees in different countries due to varying regulations and company policies, leading to disparities in employee experiences.

Pros: I spend close to 10 years (2012-2022) across various sales/account management roles in inside sales, PSU, SMB, etc. So I guess my 2 cents would give some value: -Sales and customer focused. -If you enjoy high pressure sales environment, a great place to be. -Org takes care of the employees/ benefits. I mean it. benefits, business travel quality, etc. -Great bonding & relationship with fellow peers. -Sales performers are rewarded and recognized. A very satisfying feeling that money cannot buy. (sales champions, chairmans club ,etc) -Great products, strong channel & partner ecosystem. -Partners, customers respect the brand. Makes the selling fun, challenging and a bit easy. -Account manager have power, authority and accountability. -Entire org will come forward to win a deal for and with you. -Fast, less bureaucratic, focus on execution and speed.
Cons:
-The experience is not uniform and will vary from team to team, manager to manager. While I was fortunate to have amazing managers, peers, I did see certain segments /managers were toxic, career derailing for a few of my friends. Situation can get political/diplomatic. -unrealistic sales number pressure. -you need a bit of luck -commit pressure is unreal at time. (you will love it or hate it) -not every product sells. For eg servers, webex, security sales is tough. So if you are getting in these product sales role - do your research. -The IT hardware is getting commoditized with transformation of SAAS, cloud. Has lots a bit of its charm in recent years. -Cloud, SAAS, Security is paying better these days. (2023). -Career movement / horizontally/ globally is limited. -work life balance very bad if you are in India. I have spend 70% of my weekends working (no one asks, but expects). Something that flows from top, especially in India. Not sure if that has changed since 2022.
-No career/skip manager discussions for professional growth. 

I left Cisco in 2022 as I didn't see any guidance on career growth, plan. I was getting bored. I went ahead for an interview outside to merely assess my market value and get some insights outside of Cisco world. I was shocked at the industry comp being offered. (mind you, i never asked for a single raise. I just believed in Cisco).  Having said, Cisco has been wonderful in so many ways for me. I'll always be grateful and Cisco will always hold a special place. There is never a dull moment and it will prepare you for your future.  I was lucky to be a Cisco.

Pros: I guess you could say 401k match is comparable to other competitors. Health care options - HMO / PPO with excellent benefits (like low co-pay, etc.) ESPP are a good benefit you should take advantage of. Work from home option is a perk. There are a lot of excellent engineers with a breadth of knowledge that you can reach out to for assistance. Most are willing to help and are friendly. People are smart here. For the most part. There are bonuses as well. Paid bi-annually. Amount is based on your grade / company performance / personal performance.
Cons: Let's list them: 1- middle managers are more or less cheerleaders. Esp people managers. They are also bogged down in a lot of busy meetings. So, you get ignored, for the most part. Not because of you. They are too busy. In busy meetings. Which are stacked. 2 - career stagnation. you will not move ANYWHERE unless you apply internally, which takes, what? 15 to 25 internal interviews? this is pointless and discouraging. 3 - constant layoffs. not always based on performance. in fact, the reason is never revealed to you. So no one knows why / how they were targeted. And its usually annually. right before X-Mas holidays. NICE. Cisco LOVES RIFs. And the funny thing is, they encourage you to apply internally. As if its that easy. See above. 4 - stock price is stagnant and not going anywhere. And hasn't gone anywhere for a lot of years. Well, maybe it trickled up by a few dollars per share. So those RSU benefits I listed above? You won't get rich, folks. 5 - Pointless numerous meetings with people managers, bi-weekly, 1:1. Expecting us to "grow, grow, grow." God forbid you don't look busy on your timesheets for your billing hours. They also expect you to know the management chain. When you are near the bottom. OKAY. Sure, I will memorize the names and roles of those 6 layers up, and talk candidly about their visions and what they are seeking. 6 - Mgmt - If you have a toxic manager, you will have a miserable experience. Because this company is stagnant. So you are stuck on the team unless you apply internally. And of course, pass those 25 interviews. Which can take a year and a half. 7 - Upper Mgmt - Don't ever reach out directly to them unless you want to get burnt. They expect you to reach out to their assistant directly. Assuming they have an assistant. They can't / won't be bothered. 8 - Internal technical training - yes they have it. And its not the best. Try 3rd party vendors which are far superior, like INE. 9 - Salary increase. Doesn't exist. And if it does, its basically nothing. Better to simply quit and come back as a different grade. Also salaries are on lower end of the spectrum in a comparable role at a competitor. Salaries depend quite a bit on your geographic region as well.

Pros: Remote work 100% in some roles/business units. Bonuses around 10-15%. Extreme flexibility with location -- my department didn't care if people wanted to relocate (to other countries even!). Decent work/life balance.
Cons: Remote culture means it's hard to build connections. Lack of leadership vision. Every quarter it was all about VP shuffling. Very hard to get promoted, very hard to get salary lift. I was there for 3 years before they offered me equity (a very paltry 5-figure amount to be paid over 4 years). Salary is nowhere near FAANG equivalent. 2x year layoffs. US health insurance was very Cali-focused, so if you're trying to use it or live outside of California, be prepared for $$$ visits and prescriptions. There isn't a lot of prestige to the Cisco name anymore (despite what they tell you internally). Cisco bungled the WebEx opportunity during the pandemic. If you are still early and energetic in your career, get what you can out of the experience in a year or two, and plan to leave. For those of you mid-late career, this could be a good place to 'rest and vest' if you can survive the layoff seasons.

Pros: Health Insurance: Most companies, including Cisco, offer health insurance benefits to their employees. This is an important benefit as it covers medical expenses and provides financial security for the employee and their family. Retirement Plans: Many companies offer retirement plans such as 401(k) or pension plans. Cisco's retirement plan may include matching contributions to the employee's savings. Life Insurance: Cisco may offer life insurance benefits that provide financial support to the employee's beneficiaries in the event of their death.
Cons: Cost: While employee benefits are designed to be a benefit to the employee, some benefits can be expensive. Employees may have to pay a portion of the cost of their benefits package, which can be a financial burden. Limited Coverage: Not all benefits packages offer comprehensive coverage. Some benefits may have exclusions or limitations that could limit the employee's access to the care they need. Inflexibility: Some benefits packages may not be flexible enough to meet the needs of all employees. This could include limitations on vacation time, inflexible work schedules, or rigid healthcare options.

Pros: High-Quality Products: Cisco's products are known for their high quality, reliability, and performance. This makes them a popular choice for businesses of all sizes. Advanced Security Features: Cisco's security appliances are some of the most advanced in the industry, with features like intrusion prevention, firewall, and VPN capabilities. Excellent Technical Support: Cisco offers excellent technical support to its customers, with a variety of resources available online, as well as phone and email support.
Cons: Limited Customization: Cisco's products can be less customizable than those of some of its competitors, which can be a drawback for businesses with specific needs. Steep Learning Curve: Cisco's products require a certain level of technical expertise to use effectively, which can be a barrier to adoption for some businesses. Competition: Cisco faces competition from other networking equipment and services providers, which can make it challenging to maintain market share and profitability over time.

This seems to be taking agile software engineering to the extreme edge of chaos!

Pros: As a Systems Engineer, I can confidently say that working in this role has been a fulfilling experience. The company culture is supportive, and the team is collaborative, making it easy to work on complex projects. The management is approachable, and they provide the necessary resources to help us excel in our work. The compensation and benefits package is competitive, which makes it an attractive career option. Overall, it's a great place to work as a Systems Engineer, and I highly recommend it to anyone who is passionate about technology and looking to build a successful career.
Cons: One potential con for being a Systems Engineer is that the job can be very demanding and require long hours, especially when working on complex projects or dealing with urgent issues.

Pros: I was brought in, as most, through acquisition of my startup. • Since we were a successful startup, the people who came along were phenomenal, smart, friendly and we were all in-house... pre-covid. • My team supported product, spoke to the customer and brought those insights into the ecosystem • Nice RSU structure. • Pay was not competitive, but the bonus and RSUs were solid.
Cons: • Layoffs at Cisco occur one to two times a year. Often big. • After we were absorbed, people left and we became just an employee number. • Job position/title leveling. It happens in the first 3 months. You are moved to a more junior level. Good luck trying to find a promotion.

Pros: As a full time employee, the benefits are many, employees are pampered. Work environment is very friendly, open culture, zero micro management. Flexibility in working hours. Work from Anywhere is allowed 1:1 with reporting manager once a week Quarterly development review with reporting manager once every Quarter. Opportunities for doing stretch assignment with other teams Career development is encouraged, company invests in developing your skillset.
Cons: During Internal Transfer, It is very difficult to get the company to pay you on par with someone who is hired from external organization for the same role. Annual performance review works great if manager has a good opinion irrespective of what/how much work was done. Annual appraisal, stock options, bonus amount etc are perks reserved for manager's favorite.

Pros: Solutions continue to get better. Work, Life, Balance is for real and led by example. Pay is competitive. Benefits are top notch for those with families. Upper Management is top notch (Chuck and Fran are sincere executives who truly care about their employees. Our feedback is acted on) Best example I can give is we have 3 kids, all played competitive sports including summer travel. Today 2 of them are Collegiate Athletes in 2 different States. I have been able to attend over 90% of their events, even during Q4 and most understand what a struggle that is. (Note I do hit my annual numbers so that does make it easier I will admit)
Cons: Some customers can't get over the past (a poor experiance or poor support) no matter how much you show up. Its not personal. Comp Plan changes too much but we are evolving as a Company so it is expected, if you don't like change don't come here. Note this con can be for any job. My job has only been as good as the accounts I support and my team. Past 2 years I have had decent accounts, a great support team and great manager. Before that I was on my way out due to a poor manager and average accounts. You won't know this til you take the chance and join us. If you focus on the long game, the cons are single % and change is good.

Pros: 1) Reasonable product design and delivery timelines. Has good processes that nobody follows. Good processes become bad processes if nobody follows them. 2) Company still has many great people and teams. 3) Good benefits. 4) Overall positive culture. 5) If you want to challenge yourself, you can easily do so. There are tons of hard engineering problems to crack. The company has no problem if you want to have a go at it.
Cons:
1) Sycophantic leadership chains that often care about titles and personal loyalty more than the merits of ideas or their direct reports. 2) Product management has often minimal knowledge of the industries they operate in, and often high turnover in product management. At the same time product management is given complete decision authority on features. 3) Slightly lower pay than the leading companies in Big Tech. 4) Random waves of layoffs that often impact great people, while the not-so-great people remain. Random waves of layoffs have been happening since 2014. Then they try to rehire. 5) 360 reviews are non-existent. If you have a problem with your manager, there is nobody to talk to on a regular basis. 6) Company is emotional and impulsive when it comes to 'disruptive' technologies. Instead of working internally on trying to develop products and technologies for new markets, the company prefers to acquire start-ups with great pitch books. Only to realize a couple of years later that it was too good to be true. Please perform due diligence.
7) In some JDM activities, brazen dishonesty is tolerated by the company from their counterparty. In other words, when a JDM partner substitutes its A-team for its F-team, Cisco turns a blind eye to it and does not demand accountability. As a result, Cisco ends up doing the work internally while pretending that the JDM did it.

Pros: Cisco is a big somewhat bloated company but within that massive business there are a few pockets of startup-like dynamic innovation. Like any mature company, with large installed product base the opportunity to innovate can be a challenge. It just takes more people to motivate to take risks. That said, when you get the go there are few better places to work. All the resources you need are available. There is real diversity and respect for all individuals.
Cons: It can take a lot of effort to get a green light. And every large company suffers from internal politics of some nature.

Pros: I can just tell that I'm working at a place that centers me. Even though all tech is getting hit right now with layoffs - Cisco has been working their butts off internally to move people to new positions and to lessen the impact as much as possible. I'm proud to work here.
Cons: I work as a vendor resource to the organization and not an FTE. Even still - it's great to be here.

Pros: Challenging yet flexible work environment, supportive of remote work. Good educational and social resources.
Cons: In IT, upper management is obsessed with transformation and service modernization, which is important. Teams which handle essential day-in, day-out operations support are less glamorous to management than teams which develop and promote new services. Consequentially there are poorly thought out reorganizations and layoffs every few years which lead to serious gaps in support and those depending on it being abandoned. Employees who remain can end up on teams where their roles, while still significant, are not aligned or relevant to what most of their other new team members do.

Pros: Great work culture and managers. Lot of projects (work) is available and people are available to help everywhere. The team culture in general is great across all teams. If you have to do anything with networks and networks is your long term career goal then there is absolutely no better place than Cisco. There is a LOT of training available , high end labs with tons of devices and opportunities to do so many industry level certificates and all this is free of cost.
Cons: At the end of the day it is a network support role after all. Even if you might take up a lot of automation python projects but you have to take care of your cases/.backlog. You might feel burnt out in few high severity cases as well (very similar to what software devs face when their 'feature' is about to 'go live') but that gets easier with time and experience. The nature of the job can be viewed in 2 ways : Positive : You are Sherlock Holmes who has to investigate and use your skills on multiple cases. Negative : Your work basically starts when things are going wrong. So you are almost always. dealing with a mental 'timer' as they are people waiting for you to provide solutions or answers and most of the times it is not easy. Multiple logs , timestamps, data correlation and since you are not the one who has written the code. Except few rare days mostly you will have a lot of emails to write and multiple logs to check. Salary growth can be slow ( as far as I am aware 10-18% is standard) however if your communication with management is positive and your manager assures you then it can be worth the wait. Exponential increment after a span of 2-3 years is common I have heard. This will vary a lot based on an individual's exp and work they have put in so not really a con. Lot of mandatory trainings :-P

Cons: not the best work always

Pros: Love all the people and focus on automation and innovation. People collaborate well and we have great tools like Webex that we all use and constantly improve. Security is a top priority and there is no doubt we'll continue to be a leader in the security space if we market it well. We do leadership training every year and are provided with industry training like agile principles, multi-cloud, troubleshooting, design thinking, customer service, and security. Sr management tries to communicate well, giving leaders a heads up, then letting everyone quickly know. We also love the inclusion of all people and how we celebrate people and customs from all parts of the world! Even our Russian employees were looked after without embracing what their country was doing. It was just amazing to watch how we cared for each other, as well as for people in Ukraine and our people helping others, especially in Poland.
Cons: Too many directives and micromanagement from above instead of letting Directors and Sr Managers lead and manage their budgets. For example, many still need SVP approval to travel. Layoffs are part of the company culture that is used even in the good times. People are brainwashed into thinking it is OK to treat people this way and they go along with it as they have no idea how it is to be in someone's shoes that were laid off. It is now even called a "Workforce Transition Options" as that sounds better than "layoff", and they really have no good options.

Pros: great coworkers, leadership team tries, good benefits
Cons: Layoffs ,“LR”s multiple times a year.. this really delays projects when you’re regularly losing a stakeholder or team member to LRs. During the beginning of the pandemic I was told repeatedly there was no guarantee my role was secure. The ceo claims he wont lay people off during the pandemic.. then 2 months later say theres going to be a massive layoff of 10-12% of the company in October. The additional stress and attempt to normalize the fear of losing your job constantly.. NO THANK YOU. Also huge RTP presence means lots of conservative, christian republicans. Lots of work needed in the D&I space. No formal review, no chance of promotion. People are treated as replaceable resources. 3 managers in 2 years. Didnt see a single team mate promoted in 3 years, even people that had been there 6+ years. Employees have Stockholm syndrome, “feel so lucky they survived the last LR”. The pay is horrrrible for the bay area and they do not give annual increases.. period. If youre lucky youll get a promotion every 5 years. If you are able to keep the same manager for more than 8 months. How this place makes it to the “best places to work” list..... they're clearly bribing someone.

Pros: - High caliber employees with high caliber results delivered - Great learning and development opportunities at all levels provided by Cisco - Great people that generally care about one another depending upon the department - Personally progressed several levels within my career, as a woman, with generally good support and coaching from leadership - Cisco tries to take care of their employees even in the hardest times such as redundancies - Work life balance could be good if you are in a supportive department allowing it
Cons: - Over the years as an acquisition of Cisco, they massively struggled with what to do with the AppD business. This had a major impact on innovation, strategy, and stable leadership of the AppD business. - Over the past year, Cisco is heavily focused on further integration of the AppD business creating fear-based dynamics of employees concerned about their job, pushiness when it comes to strategy moves, lack of care about impact to AppD functions and capacity drain on employees. - No psychological safety within the business at present - Employees that have been within the AppD business for years are expendable to Cisco; All executive leadership have exited and they are bringing in "Cisco people" to take over. - Some direction now in strategy, but who knows how long that will last as the trend as been to move in a certain direction and then it doesn't work out. As a hardware company, Cisco is struggling with what to do with AppD from a strategy perspective. - Work/life balance is a struggle in the Operations functions as Cisco tightens their purse strings but keeps dumping loads of work/expectations on an already lean team - Sales culture is very stressed due to all the extra burden being placed on them from an admin and process-oriented perspective. In addition, Enablement of Sales teams is a mess and creates confusion for Sales more than sets them up for success. - Extremely hard to get pay increases within teams for high performers. Wages are based on Cisco banding as a hardware company and Software companies in the market are offering significantly higher wages for the same roles. - Once Cisco came in to take over in the last year, they stopped listening to the advice of most tenured team members within AppD who knew the AppD business best. They made decisions without thinking of the impact for those "on the ground" doing the work. - New product launches going out without being fully operationalized. Rushed to market due to being behind and needing to catch up. Creating impact to Sales and potentially customer experience.

Pros: Very healthy salaries for the industry, and most jobs allow for fully remote work.
Cons: Cisco is slowly losing market share in most areas, and their only focus seems to be on switching customers to subscription models as opposed to actually developing anything truly groundbreaking. Almost 40 year old company, showing its age.

Pros:
Flexibility in how, when, and where you work is phenomenal for a company of this size.  It's a two-edged sword, but having the option to take a WebEx from home, Starbucks, airports, the beach, or in the office ... permits a level of versatility -- and fully acceptable by colleagues and management -- that would be hard to repeat elsewhere.  It's part of the culture.  The flipside is that work more easily creeps into your personal space and follows you on vacation if you're not careful.  Another consequence is that Cisco offices can feel like ghost towns.

Cisco has an immensely successful and rich portfolio and is well-positioned for the future.  But ... for the past few years, it has felt like Cisco is constantly trying to turn a corner ... and never quite making it.
Cons:
The biggest con nowadays is that Cisco is trying vigorously to grow income faster than revenue.  This translates to what seems like a never ending round of budget cuts and divestment.  Workforce reductions are becoming more common than pay raises and the value proposition to working here is becoming harder to defend.

Cisco has a severely bloated middle level of professionals.  Upward mobility is limited and the path can be vague.

Pros:
1. Great place to learn, amazing experts, who are eager to share their knowledge
2. Atmosphere of mutual respect, kindness, openness, being part of the team that has common goals
3. Atmosphere that promotes sharing knowledge, teaching, learning
4. Managers are mostly not bosses but leaders who help you grow, who are holding your back and are caring for their teams and every individual
Cons:
1. In my location salaries are reaaaaallly lagging behind competitors.
2. Rotation of workers is too fast, due to lagging salaries or organisational changes. All companies should focus on retaining employees because right now the fastest way of getting higher salary or promotion is to change your job/position. Costs and time of onboarding software engineers to complex projects is tremendous - it's not accounting or selling which everywhere is rather the same - and companies should do everything not only to get the right people but also actively encourage them to stay.
3. Too many wannabe PMs with their powerpoints, MBAs and 'groundbreaking strategies' and not enough developers.
4. Forcing 'new strategies', by PMs or other middle-management guys who want to show how important they are, which bring only chaos.
5. Inequality between wages by country - I don't believe that engineers in San Fransisco are 10 times more efficient or work 10 times harder than people in Europe, Asia etc.

Pros:
Cisco is a fun place to work, at least if you're in the sales part of the business. You can usually work from home and take flexible hours provided you're serving your customers well.

Career options are great, you can move around the business relatively easily. Opportunities to move to different countries are frequent and often encouraged.

Lots of opportunities to do side projects and define your own activities. Very little 'micro-managing'.

Rewards outside of base pay are encouraged and easy to distribute, creating a good culture with positive feedback.
Cons:
No inflationary payrises. Very difficult to get promotions without being a skilled political operative. Managers powerless to help employees in this area as they don't control any budget. Everything goes through a big HR machine. Everything and everyone is a number and cost to be reduced.

Managers are usually looking upwards focussed on their own careers, not paying attention to their employees. Can go months without a performance review or any guidance as to your own career. Promotions, payrises etc all shrouded in secrecy.

Leavers usually not replaced, or replaced slowly. Being 5 heads down is common and workload thrown to employees without any consultation or apology. This in turn affects sales commission.

Technical strategy is weak in areas due to massive in-fightning between business units. Huge egos run parts of the business. Fear is a frequently used motivational tool.

Pros: I was really proud to say that I worked at Cisco. I spend over 20 years of my life at Cisco and I really enjoyed most of it. I got to meet and work with some amazing people, most are still great friends. The early days were the best when you actually worked as part of a team. I learned a lot and enjoyed the work/life balance. The continuous training available was always top-notch. If you want to find someplace to hide and retire, there are plenty of dark holes in Cisco to do it.
Cons: Too much turnover! Senior people are put in positions they should not hold and this includes the majority of management. If you are not in your director's inner circle then you may as well pack your bags. To get into the inner circle you just have to play the game, kiss the right behinds, and squawk a lot. You don't actually have to work, you just have to be a puppet. If you dance enough little monkey, they may toss you a shilling. The "People Deal" and "Stack Rank" are horrendous and just created a cutthroat mentality, absolutely destroying teams. Lay-offs every 6 months, re-org every 2-3 years, and complete restructuring every 4-5 are exhausting!
